In the picture are all the caps I tried. The first cap was to small it didn't feel right so I made it bigger but then it was rubbing on the bearing so I made it get bigger as it goes out. I tried it with an arch in the middle for better grip but it wouldn't print without supports and the supports didn't come out clean and smooth. The cap fits a standard skate bearing perfect most of the other caps i tried were to long or not wide enough causing the spinner to not spin smooth. They clip together in the bearing for a tight fit.

description.text:
If you use Medela pumps you likely have used their storage bottles. You can use them with the pumping attachments; however, that makes the bottle extremely top-heavy and prone to tipping over (YIKES)!

I created a simple base that makes it less top-heavy and gives it a greater surface area so it is less likely to tip. It fits very snug so you have to twist a bit to get it over the threads and then it snaps onto the base flange. I've printed 2 and they fit several bottles the same way. A side note is that when not attached to bottles they snap together in a stack as seen in the picture.

This is my first ever completely custom design so I'd be happy to have constructive feedback! Enjoy!

title: MP Select Mini GT2 Y & X Belt Clips / Tensioner Monoprice
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You can use this X belt splicer to connect the X belt without the need for a tensioner. Connect the belt then tighten the screw inbetween the Y rails to tighten to desired taughtness. I originally used another GT2 tensioner for the X axis but found it would twist, it was big and bulky and generally just not needed.

For the Y axis you can zip tie the front bed in place then use this tensioner on the rear. The STL has been redesigned from the photo to move the screw on the left to above the mount to allow for more travel.

You will need to drill and tap 2 M3 screws to mount this to the bed. I used a 2.5mm / 2S drill bit & a 3mm tap.

title: Anet A8 Y Axis Motor Mount Replacement

description.text:
I am currently replacing all of the fragile acrylic parts on my Anet A8 with printed parts (681 grams replaced so far including the spool holder). I will have a backup of each part this way, and I will have something that dampens vibrations better than acrylic. Also, I can choose the color.

These parts were printed with PLA using 60 infill. They printed out very nicely without having to do much fiddling for them to fit. I was able to put in a cork motor gasket at this time to help with dampening.

Please give thanks to Simhopp and tzahov for creating these parts! I assembled them together in one place, and I modified the Y Axis Motor Mount so that the hole near the bottom extends to the bottom ... this allows for easier replacement and moving of wires, if necessary. The original Y Axis Motor Mount is also included, unaltered.

title: Wahao Duplicator 6 "Verloo Duct" Remix (40x40x20mm blower fan)

description.text:
This is a modification of Patrick Verloo's wonderful fan duct design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2118768). I modified it to use the common 40x40x20mm fan ducts that you can purchase just about anywhere. There is a slight reduction in X-axis build space (see UPDATE text below).

Fan is attached using two M3x16mm screws with nuts. If you don't have them on hand, they are available at Home Depot in the drawers in the "Screws and Bolts" section, or probably any local hardware store.

Here is a video a bridging stress test I made to test it out: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ip0M0nMjSOs

I'll try to keep it updated as Patrick continues to tweak his design.

UPDATE 2017-05-01: New STL files have been uploaded and I've included the STEP files. I've cleaned up the STLs by taking Patrick's suggestion on using the STP files and added a modified version. Here is an explanation of the 2 files:

  • The original design (wanhao_duplicator_6_fan_duct_cooling_40x20) uses the stock 40x20x20mm blower fan. There is a 20mm reduction in build space so your X axis should be 180mm instead of 200mm.

  • The newer design (wanhao_duplicator_6_fan_duct_cooling_40x20_fan_mod) uses a 40x20x20mm blower fan, but requires the removal of the "front" mount from the fan to save some space. There is a 10mm reduction in the build space so your X axis should be 190mm instead of 200mm.

comments.text: Is there a specific reason why one of the four air nozzles has a split outlet, while the other three nozzles don't? Doesn't that restrict airflow?
comments.author: Branewirt

comments.text: That is actually there to evenly distribute the airflow. Since that nozzle is directly in line with the incoming flow of air, it would "hog" and unfair share of the output. By reducing its surface area restive to the others, it gives the other nozzles more of a fair chance at the incoming air. The original designer (Antalus) did several air flow analysis in Solidworks to ensure there is even air flow between the nozzles.
comments.author: Branewirt

comments.text: To make clarity. This model is NOT optimized for the airflow. The first nozzle is just a manual adjustment to get the airflow some better. title: Leveling bracket for Sirius EQ-G tripod/mount

description.text:
The Orion Sirius EQ-G German equatorial mount does not have a bullseye level. And there are no level/flat surfaces available as a reference for checking level once the mount is fastened to the tripod.

This bracket fastens to the underside of the tripod head. Stick a 1" (25mm) diameter bullseye level on the bracket and you can level the mount before, or after, it is connected to the tripod head.

I used hot melt glue to fasten the bracket to the tripod head. I also used hot melt glue to fasten the bullseye level to the bracket.

title: PC Racing Handbrake and Button Box

description.text:
EDIT 3/26/17 - Wrong version of base.stl was uploaded, and some parts were in the wrong orientation for printing. Correct versions are now available.

I wanted to upgrade the old handbrake setup with a custom analog handbrake and button box. Instead of using a simple switch for the signal, it uses a rotary potentiometer to be a bit more realistic. I used a Teensy 3.2 to read the signals and send them to the PC over USB. You can use the handbrake as a standalone unit without the button box, but you will have to make an enclosure for the Teensy and wiring.

Tools

  • Dremel or sandpaper
  • Drill
  • Socket/wrench for M6 bolts/nuts
  • 2mm hex driver for M3 screws

Parts List

  • (1) Teensy 3.2: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13736
  • (2) Teensy Header Kit: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13925
  • (1) Rotary Potentiometer - 10k Ohm, Linear: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9939
  • (1) USB microB Cable - 6 Foot: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10215
  • (16) Cherry MX Switch: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13834
  • (1) 5pcs 6x8cm Double-side Prototype PCB Universal Printed Circuit Board: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0147YM3DG/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • (1) 8mm Shaft 150mm Linear Motion Rod: I had a spare one of these from my printer. I could not find a 150mm length rod, but here is a 10in version: https://www.vxb.com/8mm-Shaft-10-Hardened-Rod-Linear-Motion-p/kit14127.htm
  • (1-3) Springs (I used 3): https://www.menards.com/main/tools-hardware/fasteners-fastener-accessories/specialty-fasteners/springs/1-4-x-2-7-16-x-032-wg-extension-springs-1-pcs/p-1444440208368-c-9553.htm?tid=-9060762992386579289
  • Wire: I used wire from an old ethernet cable
  • (1) Styrene Sheet Plastruct sss-108 (used for front and rear cover of button box): https://www.amazon.com/Plastruct-PLS91106-SSS-108-White-Styrene/dp/B0000WS9WY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1490499076&sr=8-1
  • (4) M6x1.0 Bolts (length should be approximately thickness of your mounting surface plus 15mm): http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-M6-1-0-x-35-mm-Zinc-Plated-Steel-Hex-Bolt-2-per-Bag-802578/204281412
  • (4) M6x1.0 Nuts: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Crown-Bolt-M6-ZINC-METRIC-HEX-NUT-10-9-5-Pieces-40678/202836255
  • (4) M6 Washers: http://www.homedepot.com/p/M6-Zinc-Plated-Flat-Washers-4-Piece-803548/204276430
  • M3 Screws: https://www.amazon.com/Dophee-120Pcs-Button-Stainless-Assortment/dp/B01A6T70IE/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1490499861&sr=8-1

Optional Parts

  • (1) Toggle Switch: Any 2 position toggle switch will work. Ex: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9276
  • (1) uxcell 10 Pcs 2.54mm Pitch 4 Pins DIP Mounting Photo Coupler PC817: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00S4YRMB4/ref=od_aui_detailpages00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • (1) 1K ohm resistor: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13760
  • (1) JST Connector pair (you can use any 2 pin connector here, or solder the wires instead): https://www.amazon.com/Electop-Connector-Wire-Cable-100mm/dp/B01LN0XE94/ref=sr_1_7?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1490497893&sr=1-7&keywords=jst+connector+pair

The toggle switch is used to add some functionality. Some games do not support an analog signal for the handbrake, so the switch is setup to switch from analog mode to digital mode, which will simulate a button press when you pull the handbrake past a certain threshold. Some games only support one controller/joystick at a time, so I added the PC817 photo coupler and resistor to send the signal to my G27 wheel, which simulates a button press on the G27 wheel. The JST connector is between the button box and G27 shifter so I can separate them if needed.

Wiring

Handbrake: Only three wires are needed for functionality of the handbrake. Gound and Positive are soldered to the outside pins on the potentiometer, and the analog signal wire is soldered to the center pin. It does not matter which pin is ground or positive.

Buttons: All buttons have one pin connected to ground, and the other to various digital input pins on the Teensy.

Toggle Switch: One pin to ground, and the other to a digital input pin.

PC817: Data Sheet: http://www.farnell.com/datasheets/73758.pdf
Pin 1: 1K resistor connected to Teensy pin
Pin 2: Teensy Ground
Pin 3: JST Connector Ground (Black)
Pin 4: JST Connector Positive (Red)

The JST connector is wired to where the 2 wires that connected to the limit switch in my old setup here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:646368
Im not sure if this was necessary, but I did power on the wheel and test which wire was positive and negative with a multimeter. The red JST connector wire was soldered to the wire with +5 volts and the G27 shifter, and the other wire soldered to ground.

Teensy:
One set of the header kit is soldered to the PCB, and the other is soldered to the Teensy. This allows you to remove the board easily if needed. The final pinout for the board is shown below. It is probably not the most efficient way to wire everything, but it works. If you make changes here, you will have to change to code.
Referencing this diagram: https://cdn.sparkfun.com/datasheets/Dev/Arduino/Boards/card7a_rev1.pdf

GND: Common ground between all buttons, toggle switch, and PC817 (Pin 2)
Pin 0: Button 1 Signal Wire
Pin 1: Button 2 Signal Wire
Pin 2: Button 3 Signal Wire
Pin 3: Button 4 Signal Wire
Pin 4: Button 5 Signal Wire
Pin 5: Button 6 Signal Wire
Pin 6: Button 7 Signal Wire
Pin 7: Button 8 Signal Wire
Pin 8: Button 9 Signal Wire

Vin:
AGND: Handbrake Gound (Pin 1 or 3 on the potentiometer)
3.3V: Handbrake Positive (Pin 1 or 3 on the potentiometer)
Pin 23: Handbrake Signal (Pin 2 on the potentiometer)
Pin 20: Button 16 Signal Wire
Pin 19: Button 15 Signal Wire
Pin 18: Button 14 Signal Wire
Pin 17: Button 13 Signal Wire
Pin 16: Button 12 Signal Wire
Pin 15: Button 11 Signal Wire
Pin 14: Button 10 Signal Wire

Code Setup

  • First follow the instructions here to install the required software: https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/td_download.html
  • You will need to change the "USB Type" to "Keyboard + Mouse + Joystick" which is shown here: https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/teensyduino.html
  • Open up the Button_Box_and_Handbrake.ino file, and upload it to your Teensy.
  • You can open the serial monitor to make sure the signals are working.
  • To make sure windows is getting inputs from the Teensy, follow instructions here to open joy.cpl and view inputs: https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/td_joystick.html

After you upload the code to the Teensy, all you have to do in the future is plug in the USB to your computer and it will show up as a joystick. Cycle the handbrake at least once after you plug it in to automatically calibrate the endpoints. If you need to re-calibrate, while you are using it, press buttons 1, 7, 10, and 16 (the four corners) at the same time, and cycle the handbrake. I have never had to do this since it re-calibrates every time you plug it in, but I thought it would be a nice feature if it was ever necessary. The toggle switch will alternate between digital and analog mode. I leave mine in analog mode unless the game does not support it.

Assembly

Detailed pictures will be added if there is enough interest

Handbrake

Printed Parts List:

  • (1) Base
  • (1) Base Cover
  • (1) Handle
  • (1) Potentiometer Mount
  • (1) Potentiometer Cover

  • (1) Handle Mount

  • Sand the round sections of "Base," "Base Cover," and "Handle Mount" parts until the parts don't bind.
  • Make sure the M6 bolts slide freely through the holes in the bottom of the "Base." If they don't move freely, drill out the holes slightly larger.
  • Glue 2 of the M6 nuts into the hex holes in the bottom of the "Base" using a small amount of super glue.
  • Attach the potentiometer to the "Potentiometer Mount" using the nut and washer it comes with. You may have to drill out this hole.
  • Make sure the spinning part of the potentiometer fits in the side hole of the "Handle Mount." This should be a tight enough fit that the potentiometer does not slip inside the hole while in use.
  • Insert the 8mmx150mm Rod into the "Handle." This will be a very tight fit. I have found the best way to do this is to put the rod in a drill and drill the rod into the part.
  • Remove the rod, and repeat the process in the previous step with the "Handle Mount."
  • Slide the rod into the slot on of the "Base Cover," and re-attach the Handle to the other end. You can use an M3 screw as set screw to hold the rod in place, but I found this was not necessary.
  • Using M3 screws, screw one end of each of your springs into the bottom of the "Handle Mount."
  • Using M3 screws, screw the other end of each spring into the "Base."
  • Using 4 M3 screws, attach the "Base Cover" to the "Base," and make sure everything is moving freely.
  • Rotate your potentiometer to the approximate center position, and attach it to the side of the "Base" using 2 M3 Screws.
  • Slide 3 wires through the hole in the back of the "Base" and solder them to the potentiometer.
  • Attach the "Potentiometer Cover" using 2 M3 Screws.
  • Solder the other ends of the potentiometer wires to Teensy. You can also add your own 3 pin connector here instead of hard wiring to the Teensy.
  • Bolt the assembly to your mounting surface using 2 M6 bolts.

Button Box

Printed Parts List:

  • (2) pcb mount
  • (4) spacer
  • (1) Button
  • (1) box
  • (2) Button Cover
  • (1) Rear PCB Mount OR Rear PCB Mount 1 Piece
    Optional mounting brackets:
  • (1) Bolt Mount
  • (2) Bolt Mount2

I used the Rear PCB Mount which only covers the middle section on the back of the button box. The front faceplate and gaps on either side of the back were made with the styrene sheets. The wiring was made up as I went, but I started with mounting the Cherry MX Switches to the PCBs by drilling out many holes. I then soldered the Teensy headers to the center PCB, and secured the PCBs together using the "pcb mount," "spacer," and some M3 screws. This is a good place in the assembly to finish the wiring and upload the code to make sure everything works as intended. Screw the "Rear PCB Mount" into the "pcb mounts," and then into the "Box." Make your faceplate and rear covers using the "Box" as a template. I used a sheet of paper, and punched a screwdriver through each of the holes to make a drilling template. I cut out 2 rectangular holes using a dremel and cutoff wheel that are just big enough for each group of 8 buttons. Start with a small hole, and make adjustments until everything fits. Once you have the faceplate on, start sanding the insides of the "Button Covers" until they fit over one group of buttons. I originally intended to use screws to attach the "Button Covers" to the faceplate, but it wasn't easy to line up perfectly to drill holes, so I just used some superglue at each corner instead. The mounting brackets are attached with screws, and M6 nuts are glued into the hex holes on the "Bolt Mount" part to mount the box to a flat surface.

I think I have covered just about every step of the assembly process, but I probably missed some things. Feel free to ask questions if I need to clarify anything.

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Wood with larger bed

Notes:

Printed with 100% infill on parts with springs attached.
Sanding is required for smooth operation of the handbrake on the

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eIFAvu9a4Fe

print_settings.Notes:: Infill density is up to you, but I fancy making things built to last.

description.text:
This model is my first try at using 3D printing tools. I didn't know all the nitpicks about how things work when creating this, so I just modeled something I thought looked nice. I used Autodesk 123D Design for this model.

Most of the design is based off of Metin Seven's raygun model. That can be seen here: http://www.metinseven.com/projects/a8Y60

I couldn't find an original file of his model, so I recreated my own from scratch using reference pictures, along with making a few personal additions I thought would give it a more Art Deco/50's look.

At 100% scale, it's roughly 16mm tall and 19mm long when fully assembled and fits nicely in my average sized hand.

Extrusions & holes have been added in certain places so realignment wasn't an issue during the final assembly, but the my tolerances ended up being far from perfect and I had to take dremel to most of the parts.

If you would like decide for yourself how the parts should be printed (whether cut up, printed as one solid part, or create your own tolerances for the plugs and holes) here is a link to the original fully assembled .123dx file.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B3eRlYSYMqVZclY1RFhwQ1BGZms/view?usp=sharing

I may consider revising my tolerances and updating this thing so parts fit better in a future version.

Printer:

MP Select Mini 3D Printer

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I printed the handle and main body with a 4mm wall thickness to make it virtually impossible to crush in the hand. The white parts of the raygun I printed with 2-3mm wall thickness.

Infill density is up to you, but I fancy making things built to last.

description.text:
After I printed Andrew Bougie's mini-SNES case for my Raspberry Pi 3, I decided that I wanted to add a status LED to show when the system was running. However, the hole in the case is ~3 mm, and I only had 5 mm LEDs.

I created this thing to align and hold a 5 mm LED in place behind the existing hole. I just epoxied the part to the bottom corner as shown in the Fusion 360 diagram. Once it was set, I inserted the LED, which stays in place via friction.

The front wall of the upper half of the case is thicker at the bottom for some reason (improved bed adhesion, perhaps). This creates a very strange backward slope on the interior front wall as it moves downward. Since the LED holder complements that slope, the top of the holder is thicker than the middle, which makes the case a little more fiddly to put together. As the cover photo demonstrates, however, it does work. I believe the easiest method is to slide the top half of the case onto the LED holder on from the front and slightly tilted. I may eventually change this part so the case fits a little looser on top.

description.header: I want a cool LED, too
description.text:
Configuring a Raspberry Pi 3 for the status LED

The status LED works by taking advantage of the GPIO pin for the Pi's built in serial terminal. The pin goes high when the system boots, and remains high until it goes into shutdown mode (or a program changes it).

With the Pi 2, this status LED setup apparently would have just worked automagically. However, the addition of Bluetooth on the Pi 3 mucked things up. One of the changes that resulted was that the serial port became disabled by default. That prevents the LED from remaining lit after boot.

To fix it in Raspbian Jessie, you'll need to edit the /boot/config.txt file to turn the serial port back on. Just add the following line at the end of the file: 

enable_uart=1

The usual command to run nano editor to edit the file from the pi's command shell is: 

sudo nano /boot/config.txt

Since the contents of /boot partition are what's visible to windows when you have a raspbian installation mounted there, you could also just edit the file that way.

Wiring the status LED

  1. To make the wires to connect the LED to the pi, I cut female-female breadboard jumpers in half. You need two jumpers if you want the wires to be different colors (my jumpers were red and black), but you could just cut one jumper in half and color code each with a sharpie or nail polish or something.

    Alternately, you could just crimp a female dupont connector onto a red wire and another on a black wire.

  2. You need a current limiting resistor for any LED project. If you don't feel like Ohm's Lawyering, the easiest way is to use an LED resistance calculator like this one

    2A. In the calculator, I used 5V as the source voltage. I believe the GPIO pins are actually supplying 3.3V, but 5V as your value works fine. Doing so just makes the resistor higher than necessary and thus the LED a bit dimmer. Worst case is that the LED simply doesn't do anything until you pick a smaller resistor. In return, this gives you the ability to test the LED on one of the 5V power pins, which are sourced directly from the USB power supply rather than from the Pi's limited power regulator. That means you are unlikely to fry the Pi if you use a resistor that's way too small (though that'd be really difficult with my LED regardless).

    2B. Normally an LED wants around 20 mA forward current to get full brightness, but GPIO pins can only source about 16 mA. For the calculator, I put in 15 mA. The lower number will, again, merely make the resistor a little bigger and the LED a bit dimmer. That is fine. You won't really notice.

    2C. The Vf (forward voltage drop of the LED) depends on what type of LED you use (yellow, red, blue, ultrabright, etc.). If you don't have a data sheet, the calculators will give you typical values that will likely work. For my purple/UV LED, this number is 3.3V.

    2D. The Ohm's Law version of the calculator website is (Supply voltage - Forward Voltage) / Forward Current = Resistance, with forward current being specified in Amps. For my numbers, that's (5 - 3.3) / 0.015 = 113.33333. If you don't have the exact rating on hand (I didn't, because 113 and 1/3 ohms is hardly a standard EIA value), then you can use the next standard rating that's higher. In fact, that's exactly what the calculator website did: it told me to use 120 ohms.

    Note that in my case, the next lower standard resistor (110 ohms) would probably also work, as 3 ohms is within the 5% tolerance rating of many common resistors. 110 would be even more likely to work if you were willing to allow 16 mA of forward current instead of 15, as that'd only need a 106.25 ohm resistor, but I chose 15 mA to allow a safety margin. As a rule, it's better to use a resistor that's a little bit high than one that's too low. Better safe than sorry.

    Sadly, I didn't have any 110 or 120 ohm resistors. In this situation, you can do like I have and put two (or more) smaller resistors in series. The resistances simply add together. I had a 100 ohm and a 22 ohm, giving me a total of 122 ohms. Good enough! I just twisted one end of each resistor together and soldered them. The wiring diagram would simply show an extra resistor to the left (or right) of the existing one.

  3. If possible, test your wiring with a breadboard before you make the permanent version.

  4. Solder one end of the resistor(s) to the longer pin of the LED (the anode). Solder the other end of the resistor(s) to your red wire. Refer to the wiring diagram.

  5. Solder the black wire to the shorter leg of the LED (the cathode).

  6. Insulate your work. I used heat shrink tubing. Since my jumper wires and resistor leads are so thin, I also inserted a short length of nylon filament inside the tubing before heating it. This acts as strain relief to keep the joints from bending much. As the result is a bit long and hits the USB ports, I just bent the LED leads to an angle.

  7. The red wire should be connected to GPIO 14. (Physically, on the Pi 3 header this is pin 8. If you hold the Pi 3 so its USB and Ethernet ports are down, the correct pin on the header is the 4th one down on the right side. Other Raspberry Pi pinouts may or may not vary.)

    This pin is normally the serial terminal's Tx. As long as the serial port is enabled and no programs change the pin, it will go high (supply +V) whenever the pi boots, and go low (no power) when the system goes into shutdown mode and it's safe to disconnect power. The LED may or may not flicker when booting (text being sent to the terminal).

  8. The black wire can connect to any of the ground pins. For no particular reason, I'm using pin 30 (the 15th pin down on the right side of the header).

description.text: http://to-shirt.com/

This is simply a magazine to hold wire ferrules. Its pretty much stolen from every medium caliber weapon ie 20mm and up I have worked on at some point in my life. If you have big hands, or just don't like spilling ferrules into possible running energized equipment, YOU NEED THIS!

It also allows you to put on a wire ferrule without the absolutely stupid acrobatics of putting on a ferrule, holding it so it stays on (which is rarely seems to) and then trying to get the crimper on it.

In this case, simply strip the wire, grab the crimper with the ferrule magazine on it, and put the wire in, push it through the magazine feed hole where the metal ferrule then is exposed into the crimp section, crimp the wire, and pull it out. VIOLA! The wire is crimped and the next ferrule is put into place for the next crimp!

In this case, zip tie it to your crimpers as shown, feed your ferrules into the magazine, and then put a folded zip tie into the magazine to act as a spring. I will work on a spring system later, or, if you all have any ideas, go for it.

This should have been invented about 60 years ago, but, we do what we can. Modify to your hearts content and happy wiring!
Still needs to be tested!

comments.text:
Your ratio is incorrect.
When it comes to worm driven gears , the worm is always considered as 1.
So , with 16 teeth on the gear the correct ratio is 16:1
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text:
Wikipedia -
With a single start worm, for each 360° turn of the worm, the worm-gear advances only one tooth of the gear. Therefore, the gear ratio is the "size of the worm gear - to - 1". Given a single start worm, a 20 tooth worm gear reduces the speed by the ratio of 20:1.
comments.author: JML31347

comments.text:
But your wrong , it takes 16 turns of the worm to rotate your main gear 1 rotation.
The Wikipedia description does not apply here.
At any given time there is only ONE lead in engaged with the gear , by such worm equals 1 and gear equals 16
16:1 ratio

author: sneakgamer

description.text:
Coral frag rack and magnet holder. Holds up to 21 frags, you can superglue your magnets in after printing. The holder actually works better if you use it with the printed side facing the aquarium (magnets closest to you).

The holes in the middle row are a bit larger than the front and back rows, so you can either have your frag plugs fit tight or fit loosely. (made for 3/4" frag plugs). Print in ABS for best maintainability in a reef aquarium.

I got the Black Rubber Coated neodymium disc magnets (1" diameter x 1/2" thick) with protective rubber coating from K&J Magnetics. (DX08BR-N52). These are SUPER strong, so you might want to go a bit weaker if your aquarium is thinner than 1/2" glass.

If you don't print at 100% infill it can absorb and ultimately get water-logged, which will make it heavier.

A nice tool holder that fits over any 20mm extrusion.
In my case on my MendelMax 1.5. It has 5 circular holes which will fit most type of screw drivers.
And one rectangular hole which holds my scissors.

I have printed it with 10% infill, 3 solid bottom 4 solid top.  
The bridge is 20mm, I have used a fan for this.

print_settings.Notes:: Only used supports when printing the fan blade to support the center hub area.

title: 60mm Radial Fan To Blower Fan Conversion

description.text:
I found the conversion originally done, but it wouldn't fit the needs of my specific fan. The fan I used was an old 60mm CPU fan by Antec.

The height of the lower case was incorrect due to the motor I used (the blower wheel hit the lid when assembled), and the blade direction was wrong. I included both blades and case pieces for left and right rotations. I needed to make a few other adapter pieces for my specific fan motor as I disassembled it to make it work, and I also removed some other holes that weren't needed, and the text which was causing problems when printing for me.

Just a remix for my specific application. Thanks to the original designer!

comments.text: Cardboard might be airtight if you manage to tape all the gaps and holes, but it is not an effective barrier against moisture and will not prevent the filament from getting humid. Moisture will slowly diffuse into the cardboard from the outside, and then again out of the cardboard into the inside. This box will only slow down the rate at which the filament absorbs moisture. You need to coat the entire box with a waterproof paint or varnish to make it effective.
comments.author: DrLex

comments.text:
These are exactly my thoughts looking at this design.
Using the Box as a holder is a nice trick, but keeping out the moisture (what else you want an airtightness?) is not accomplished by it at all.

title: Raspberry Pi Official Case Mount for Maker Select / Wanhao D13
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I purchased a Vilros Raspberry Pi 3 Starter Kit Bundle and they included what I believe is a self branded version of the Official Raspberry Pi case. I wanted a way to mount it to my Maker Select V2.1 without any kinds of fasteners, glue, hook and loop, zip ties etc. nor did I want to do any modifications to the enclosure case.

You can place the official Raspberry Pi case in the holder with either the cables coming out of the top or the bottom. If you have the cables coming out of the bottom you will only have access to the ethernet port and two of the 4 USB ports. I only need 1 USB port for OctoPrint and that is it so I am fine with the cables coming from the bottom.

There is an optional piece that stabilizes the holder from rocking. It isn't necessary but it is there if you want it. I am using it.

My time and PLA went into designing this thing. If this design blesses your life in some way, feel free to favor me with a tip as thanks. Gratuities are not required, but are definitely appreciated. You can tip me any amount that you would like here: https://www.paypal.me/brysonjack
Make sure to include a comment telling me which design it is. Thanks in advance.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

85%

Notes:

The Raspberry Pi is so light that I am not really worried about structural failure of the holder. If I was, I would have printed it with the layers going vertical instead of horizontal and I probably would have printed it solid. I used PLA with a Honeycomb infill. Do what you feel is best.

description.text:
-=[ Real Women Have Curves ]=-

Please Note: This is ART, no different than any of the works of the Masters from years past.

While I enjoy the nude female body as much as the next guy... ok may not not quite as much as that guy, but at least as much as the guy sitting next to him... I have downloaded quite a few of the nude female forms from here to print as my (and my printer's) abilities grew. However, in my never to be humbled opinion, all of the YL's modeled here could use a Twinkie or two if we were being honest with each other. So what's a guy to do? He creates his own girl, of course! Mwahaha! (bellowed, while evilly twisting one's mustache) :)

As you can see in the screencap from MakeHuman, the girl is supposed to have a punk style hair cut. When this is loaded into Slic3r, however, the model is not manifold and reports numerous errors. I didn't notice that at first since I mainly slice with Cura (better, easier to remove supports). Had I bothered to look at the layer preview, though, before printing, I would have seen something a little off. The girl's hair to be exact! I guess in it's eagerness to repair the mesh, Cura decided that a bald chick might make a better model. I am including the original files in case anyone feels froggy and wants to see about repairing it.

I created the original model in MakeHuman running under Ubuntu 16.04 LTS, exported as an OBJ, imported into MeshLab and exported as an STL from there.

description.text:
This is a foot I designed for use on a BigDelta 3D Printer I'm building. The BigDelta uses Openbuilds 4040 V-Slot for vertical towers.

The foot is cushioned by a cut-in-half squash ball which is very close to 40mm diameter. The idea is to isolate vibration and give the printer an ultra quiet operation.

The design is mean to avoid the need to tap the ends of the 4040 for it to be secured. Instead it uses a wedge-like mechanism inspired by some kinds of drywall anchors. There are holes for M3x16 bolt to be screwed into the part. The holes taper down to smaller than the bolt diameter, so that as the bolt is screwed in, the parts to each side are pushed outwards, and bind against the inner walls of the extrusion.

Additionally there is a channel for wiring to pass through the center of the 4040, and a funnel like feature to help guide wires out the foot piece. I plan to use it for the endstop wiring, and possibly some lighting around the top of the printer if I get around to it.

I don't play squash, so I don't know much about the different types, but I ended up getting double yellow dot style. It ended up being more squishy than I expected, but maybe other styles are better suited. The ball can be carefully cut in half with an xacto knife, using the seam of the ball as a guide.

Printer:

Voxel Ox 8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used eSun solid red PETG. Sliced with simplify3d, I haven't yet found a really good setting for the support interface layer with PETG, its pretty rough as can be seen in one of the pics. But the finish of that surface is under the squash ball so it doesn't matter!

PETG has a good amount of flex that I think helps the screw to push the parts out of the way. A harder material like PLA might crack if flexed the same amount (not sure, haven't tried).

print_settings.Notes:: All pieces can be printed without support.

title: Dyson V6 Trigger charging wall mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tired of always searching your charging adapter for the Dyson? Tired of having the Dyson lying around right in the way while charging?
Print out this nifty wall mount, which uses your original power cord (without any modifications) to create a wall mount, in which your Dyson V6 Trigger is automatically charged once sled in.
It's neither magic nor rocked science - just an easy and durable DIY alternative to an (in my opinion) expensive commercial product.

To insert the power cord, slide it in the barrel plug from the top in the hole (make sure the cable slides through the provided slot) until it reaches the bottom. Turn the plug it to the right (about 45°) to hold it in place.

description.text: A camera Tripod,  swiss-arca ball head, and this 3D printed quick release plate make for a simple, light weight easel. Make a few of these and you can switch wet drawings out with while painting en plein air. Attach with epoxy.

• Flip the model so the larger, top area is on the bottom of the printing bed.

  • Cut wood. I used 11x17" 1/4" birch plywood, but it felt sturdy enough to go larger - I wouldn't exceed 18X24 without adding more horizontal support.

  • Epoxy the plate - large side facing the wood. Let dry for 24 hours.

  • Use!

author: efra1

description.text:
This is work in progress...

I made this holder (stand) for my Wileyfox spark plus to mount the phone in the car above the speedometer.

So the clamps to mount the holder (stand) are still required.
http://k8200.vandegroepjes.nl

Update: This model seems to be a fail. Edf at this size is just not powerful enough to make it fly. However if you are interested in designing your own planes, this might help. Follow the printing instructions, run the parts through your slicer, and inspect the results. If you are designing your own, remember that 0.6mm is the thinnest section you should use for it to show up on the slicer.

You need advanced printing skills to do this.
Can be printed on a cheap printer like an Anet A8 if you have it properly calibrated.

Many thanks to Dave Pinchbeck for helping with design and printing advice.
Thanks to 3DLabPrint for the inspiration.
Original 3d model: https://grabcad.com/library/mirage-2000--3

This is an experiment so i could learn how to design rc planes to print.

I HAVE NOT FLOWN IT YET!
It is a work in progress.
I might have to re-design the wing, and change the thrust angle.
Yeah, i know thats a bit lame, but i cant get a good launch, not enough speed.
Wont hand launch, and my bungee wont launch it. Might work with wheels, i dont know.
If you manage to fly it before i do, let me know how it goes.

I dont know if the thrust angle is right. You might need to cut extra cheater holes for enough thrust. The CG is a guess, but should be pretty close.
Its a bit heavy for a 50mm EDF, so you need a strong bungee and ramp to have any hope of launching it. I will not do any more this size because of the power to weight problem.

Check out the remix parts by Dcdesigns, he made internal intake ducting to help with motor power and efficiency. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463909

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

No

Notes:

Printing instructions:
0.4mm nozzle.
0.2mm layer height.
60deg bed temp.

This is an advanced print, and you need to use the advanced settings in your slicer.
You need to calibrate your bed level, extruder steps, filament temperature and retraction.
If you dont know how to do this search Youtube for tutorials.
Hotter plastic bonds better. Go as hot as you think you can with your filament.
Too hot may cause warping. Having the fan on for the whole print may cause warping, and will make weaker layer adhesion.
Do a temperature test print to find the best temperature. Here is a video explaining how temperature affects strength: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mwS_2R2mIvo
Im using Simplify 3D, however it should work fine with other slicers.
Check the results of the slicing before printing.

Slicer settings for all parts:
Retraction on.
Only retract when crossing open spaces must be OFF. Always retract. 0.2mm z hop is a good idea.
No infill.
No support.
One perimeter.

Specific settings:
No fan unless bridging or printing wing part tops, tail top or nose top.
Use the fan for the top layers on the motor mount and rear
Use brim for wings, wingtips tail, and ailerons.
The wing parts and tail use 2 bottom layers and 3 top layers.
The nose, motor mount, hatch, and rear has 2 bottom and 4 top layers.
The cockpit, battery box, and middle have no top or bottom layers.
Joiners and hatchcatch print with 100% infill.

Assembly and specs.

Mirage 2000:

785mm long, 533mm wide, 385g of printed parts.

Minimum printer size, 150x150x150.

You need:
400g of PLA filament.
EDF 50mm and esc.
2x9g servo, and extension leads.
Radio control reciever.
Velcro and styrofoam for battery.
6mm carbon tube 1x 400mm, 1x 75mm, 2x 170mm.
4x aileron hinges or print with flexible filament.
Glue, Hobbyking EPP foam glue is good.

Option parts:
"Hs1177cockpit" has a space for a hs1177 or similar camera.
"Nosevents" has vents to help cool any FPV gear and the battery.
"Wingvents is a version of the batterybox with vents in the leading egde of the wingroot, for extra air to the EDF.
"Middlevents" is the middle section with some vents in the bottom.

Assembly:
Dont glue anything yet!
Because this is a small plane, keeping the weight down was my main priority.
There are no sections or hatches to aid assembly. So it is a bit tricky.
Once its together it wont come apart easy, so take your time and get it right.

The 3 different size joiners glue into the slots between sections.
Mostly this is for alignment, but for the nose it is the only thing holding it on.
The fuselage is held together with the carbon tube. All but the nose and rear.
The wings and tail also have carbon tube for strength.

Cut out some cheater holes.
Cut them inside from the wing bracing, so that they are in the intake duct area.
Check all your electronics before assembly. You wont be able to get to a lot of it once its all glued together.
Centre your servos, check for correct motor direction, etc.
The servo lead should run forward in the "middle" section, then under the floor of the battery compartment to the cockpit.
There are very small slots at the bottom rear of "batterybox" or "wingvents" for the servo lead.
Run the motor leads through the hole provided. Glue the motor in.
Solder your battery connector to the ESC cable. Make sure its long enough.
Place the ESC in the rectangular hole behind the battery compartment. Dont glue it yet.
There is a hole in the top brace behind this to cable tie the leads to the motor.

Now the tricky parts are getting the ESC connected to the motor, and the servo leads into the cockpit.
Cut the rear tabs off the servos, run the cable forward through the section and glue the servos in place.
Glue 2 joiners and the long carbon tube into the motor mount section.
Connect the ESC and motor leads, then slip the ESC into the slot from behind.
Glue the carbon tube and joiners as you push the 2 sections together, make sue the ESC fits in the slot.
Glue the ESC in place.

Glue joiners in "middle" to fit to the battery compartment section.
Slip the battery section on the carbon tube and make sure the joiners line up.
Connect servo extension leads and run them under the battery compartment floor.
There are small gaps for the leads to slot into at the rear of the battery box, or you can cut slots for them.
Same for the esc control lead.
Make sure they are long enough to reach your RX in the cockpit.
Glue the sections together.

Thats the difficult stuff done, the rest is easy.
Just use the appropriate joiners for joining sections together, dont forget the carbon tube for the wings and tail.
If you have flexible filament, print the aileron hinges, or if using bought hinges you need to fill the gap with something or they will be a bit loose.

comments.text:
This model is not easy to make it fly. I think a propeller powered plane is a better idea for a project.
Have a look at my Mosquito. It is small, but you could make a big version, use the link to the original model and make it as big as you like.
If you really want edf, make it from foam.
INAV is a very good and cheap system for automatic flight with GPS, check it out.
Another project you might consider for university is a CNC foam cutting machine. You can make one. This will make large wings and parts from foam which is much lighter and stronger than a 3d printed plane.
https://www.google.com.au/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0ahUKEwj4iNXfzobYAhVLUbwKHeZVDTEQFghIMAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.instructables.com%2Fid%2FMake-a-CNC-Hot-Wire-Foam-Cutter-from-parts-availab%2F&usg=AOvVaw0voLkeTVfYeHJsHti5NOa-

comments.text:
How about using the design to make a female mold then fill with expanding foam. Or make a fuselage top and bottom female, heat dollar tree foam in the oven, place foam in one half of the mold and weigh it down with a mold insert (a smaller male version) to force it to the shape. Do the same to the other half (or other parts). This will make a foam shell that can be glued together.
Foam is much lighter. The 3D print can be reused.
Cover foam in fiberglass to add strength and durability (rcgroups has plenty of advice).

comments.author: Diymik

comments.text: It looks to me like you don't have openings for the ducts in the posted stl parts.
comments.author: Dcdesigns

comments.text: I designed it as solid parts with small internal features. When you print it with no top or bottom layer, and no infill, it becomes a hollow part with the flat surfaces on top and bottom open. Follow the printing instructions and preview in your slicer.
comments.author: Dcdesigns

comments.text: To get good airflow through a Ducted fan You need ducts. Having just a hollow body creates buffeting and vortexes that reduce the volume of air getting to the fan. I did a remix with ducting inside. It may need some tweaking on the ducts. I think it will be a great model when it is done. The hollow body will work just fine for a pusher prop though. I just want to help get this beautiful work in the air.

I used this video for the coin design. I used this video to see how he got text to print well and what size he printed it at to get the right results.

description.text:
A very simple wall clip for hanging a pennant or anything light that needs to hang from a rod.
Designed to be used with Command strips, but you can certainly just use double side tape.

Designed for a rod with max diameter of 10mm (~3/8"+).

Inspiration was from after receiving reward from Bamboo Renewal project on Kickstarter for rebuilding homes and workshops in Haiti.
Thanks to them for a great project!

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Notes:

I have uploaded TWO slt files:
FlagWallClip_Pair, this is a full set of two clips. It is all you'll need (besides the tape and pennant).

The FlagWallClip is just a single clip (right side). You can use this if you want to remix or print separately. You will naturally need two of these, but be sure to mirror one as this is just the right side.

I did print these flat to the bet and then used supports to make sure that the hooks bridged properly. A little sanding and they are fine.

These thumb screws are spares, in case you loose the included thumb screws. They will fit ALL Ritewing aircraft that use thumb screws.

I also made two variants for lower drag screws. See what you prefer.

The files contains 9 screws.

Using a screenshot from the game, I made a transparent layer in Photoshop and copied to the best of my ability using shapes, rather than freehand. I then deleted most of it, copied one section five times, and rotated each to make it symmetrical.

Then I saved it in various layers to SVG format, which I then imported into TinkerCAD. Job done.

Printed in black PLA, and painted the edges silver.

title: 360 Cooling Fan Mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a new mount for noen's 360 Degree Part Cooling Fan. It was designed for my upgraded Folger Tech Prusa i3.

The original "360Cooling.stl" and "360CoolingBracket.stl" parts are used together with my redesigned "360 fan mount.stl" part.

To be consistent with the original design, the screw attaching the mount to the bracket is M4, and the screws for attaching the mount to the extruder are M3 sized. However, as I didn't have any M4 screws at hand, I simply used M3 screws for this 360 cooling fan, along with some washers.

I suggest rotating the part by 90 degrees before printing to avoid using supports.

description.text:
This is a magnetic picture hanging system for hanging things on walls that you don't want / can't screw into, mar, or use adhesives.
Works very will for Drop Ceilings and for Wallpapered Rooms
Works especially well for foam-core printed pictures or posters
Good for patterns since you can fine tune / rearrange after hanging

There are two parts:
1) The Picture Hanger
This plate has holes and channels to run monofilament (fishing line) through to hold the picture. It has channels to run "straight" through vertically (for small pictures) and also has space for double wrapping the bottom for heavier pictures. You can attach this plate to your pictures with command strips or double side tape OR there is a spot on the top to glue in a small magnet (10mm x 1mm).

2) Magnet Jig
If you choose to use magnets this little jig will help you align the magnets on your pictures.

3) Drop Ceiling Clip
This is a clip for use with standard US drop ceilings. It clips into the edge of the wall and has a hole for monofilament for the hangers above. Certainly could be use separately.

So far this works very well for mounting foam core printed pictures from a drop ceiling. The monofilament is strong enough that I can easily hold six 4X6's or four 8X10s on a single line. Since they are all on the same line the alignment is spot on. Additionally since this is a friction mount, I can easily fine tune the vertically alignment to make everything line up.

If you are going to use the magnets BE SURE to make sure all magnets are aligned the same way when glueing. This will allow you to rearrange later and your pictures will stick to any holder.

UPDATE - Oct, 2017
I'm going to be posting a new version of this in early November that is much improved over this design. The main issues that I have run into after normal use is the lack of "hard" attachment to the pictures. Magnets are great, but it would be better if a way a more robust connection. If you are considering using this I would suggest holding off for a few more weeks until the revision comes out.

title: 3D printed line portrait
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
When seen close-up, it seems like it is just a bunch of random lines... But back up a bit, and you'll see the image that it forms.

I got the idea from image-to-ASCII art (Google it to find out more...) The idea behind it is that differing line densities in each block produce a different gray-scale color when seen from far away. The image was first converted to a 50x50 pixel gray-scale image, and then converted to the line blocks.

There is no STL file, as it was directly scripted to GCode using Python. I actually just want to share my idea with you. If you would like to find out more, please contact me. The script is not very user friendly yet, but it there is enough interest, I am willing to neaten up the code and distribute it.

comments.text:
Thanks!
I have definitely written code before that I would rather not have anyone see, lol.
Guidance is great, thanks. I wanted something recently that is more clever/complex than normal halftone, and this looks like it fits the bill...
comments.author: Rabun0510

comments.text:
SO, I think I have most of it figured out...
The lines are all the same thickness...
comments.author: neoteric

comments.text: Yes, they are all the same thickness, just the distance in between the diagonal lines that differs. So it is not just simply the number of diagonals (that would only give you a discrete scale of +- 10 shades) but also the distance between them. The nice thing about the diagonal lines is that as they move in from the top right corner to the bottom right (or whichever direction) their length changes, so it gives great flexibility in terms of getting a specific grey scale shade.

description.text: Van Leeuwenhoek's microscopes were very small simple instruments, with a single, yet strong convex lens (1 to 3 mm in diameter) mounted in a tiny hole in the body of the instrument. Combining this old microscope with the great cameras found on cell phones and tablets, we were able to create a very inexpensive microscope. To fabricate the objective you need to prepare one little glass ball and must be pushed into the hole on the clip until the front of the lens is flush with the housing. Alternatively, you could probably get away with using a lens from a disposable DVD drive.

author: fabiopaola

title: QAV210/180 Front bumper/LED Mount/FPV Cam mount

description.text:
This is a mix of a Bumper to protect the camera and mount a small LED strip at the same time, and a "Love seat" style camera mount. Slide the cam mount on first, and the bumper on top of that. If the post hole is too large, wrap a layer or two of tape around the bottom of the post.

Mount the camera and LED strip with strong sticky tape or glue (shoe goo works well).
Print them in TPU/TPE to make them unbreakable and protect the camera.
Both the HS1177/HS1184 and the swift etc cameras should fit. Angle is ~30°.

title: MINI MONOPRICE MINI | MPSM Select Miniature Scale Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
MINIMONOPRICE

The Mini Monoprice Mini

To teach myself modeling and 3D printing I've started working on a 1/3 ischz scale model of my Monoprice Select Mini, my first printer that I just recently bought and am loving the hell out of!

I started making this miniature to eventually use in a little stop motion video* I wanted to create to help sell my first 3D modeled-and-printed product, but to my surprise and joy those sold out even before I I finished this little printer, so no need for speed on the stop motion tip all of a sudden. although I couldn't resist making the little video loop you see up top.

*so no, it doesn't actually work. I thought this was obvious, but several people have asked me this question or where disappointed it didn't, so don't say I didn't tell you :)

I wanted to finish the model nonetheless, so I can still learn from it (which I did. a lot), maybe make that video for a second series and also give back to this community, as I've already had just as much joy of Thingiverse as of the printer itself.

Please feel free to print your own Minnie Monoprice and play with her, but do NOT use her for commercial purposes. She's not like that!

If you made one please share, I would love to see it! Also, if you've modded it, as you might have done with your real MPSM, please show me. It would be great to see different personalized Minis, as that is another thing I love about 3D printing; not one machine seems to be the same.

So far my mods also included in the scale model are:

  • robin7331's MPSM Extruder Baseplate v1 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2029972)
  • robin7331's MPSM Extruder Arm v1 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2030554)
  • Makify1's MP Select Mini Slip-On Fan Guard (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2043464)
  • CreativeTools's Universal Filament Filter and Lubricator (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067)
  • a custom knob and LEGO spinner (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2147594) that I designed myself. They are my first ever mod and the first ever thingie I shared in the verse
  • part of Sloop45's Lea Top Bust (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:642870) as the printed part in the stop motion video loop

Since I'm new to this and I just got my MPSM, I will very probably add more mods and upgrades to my real life machine. As I do, I intend to also mod and upgrade this miniature version.

While I go along and finish working on this model I'll also post pictures and videos of the process and progress on mostly my Instagram (@baschz) and some on my Twitter (@baschz as well) account, using the hashtag #minimonoprice. If you're interested :)

I'd love to hear what you think of it so far!

STILL TO DO, FIX AND IDEAS

  • Improve the main tower slots
  • Add a (version with a) real size microSD slot in the printer's base (for the video)
  • Double check and tweak all tolerances
    -Print and test everything in colour

UPDATES SO FAR

3/27/2017 Added a layer of blue painter's tape to the heated bed! (See pictures). Tell your printer to pause at height 0.13125mm and switch from blue to silver or which colours you want your bed and tape to be. Since I print on tape myself it even copied the structure. Pretty happy about this little proof of concept
P.S. print without a brim or even a skirt, since the second layer (and on) will cover those lines partly. Or do like I did (when I realized what was happening just in time :)); swiftly peel the skirt off the print bed during the colour switch

3/27/2017 Improved and uploaded the LEGO Spinner. It has some very crisp built-in easily snapable supports now

3/28/2017 Since I've added tape to the heated bed, I might just as well add a whole roll, for when I need more :) The roll in the pictures is printed on 0.13 in Colorfabb Sky Blue PLA and Colorfabb Woodfill and has almost the exact colours

https://youtu.be/dVm8qnXM0Tw

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.13125 and 0.175

Infill:

Changes per item. 20-30% on most parts, 100% on the tiny ones

Notes:

All the grey concept parts are printed in Innofil3D Grey PLA on 210 degrees Celcius on a 55 degrees heated bed in 0.175 layer height. The colourful version mostly consists out of Colorfabb PLA and was printed with a 0.13125 resolution on 200/50.

There's no need for rafts and hardly any support material. Only the main tower really needs it and I've used (Cura) support on the display to double as the display's menu, which came out pretty nice I think.

All parts are already laid down on their best side, to get the best printing results and the nicest finish on the side you'd want it most.

I've sanded a few burrs here and there, but mostly it should all just snap together. This might be different if you use other materials or settings. Obviously I've made everything so that I'll get the best results with my setup.

To put everything together you will also need two 50mm metal or plastic rods of a diameter of 3mm for the bed and two pieces of 60mm for the x-axis.

I've designed (almost) everything in Tinkercad, as I haven't had the time to really dive into other programs, but I'm well amazed so far by how much I can already do with 'just' Tinkercad!

The Lamball Bakra logo on the tower and the name and logos on the bottom were made in Illustrator, exported as .svg's and brought into Tinkercad.

This is a collection of pieces for a tabletop game my family is designing.  The creatures were all done in spore, with post production in blender, and the rest of the geometry was done in blender.

If you create more creatures on this hex base and upload them let me know.  I am always looking for more to paint and add to my game.

title: Microscope Support from cheap drill press with electronic adjustment.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello. This week i am sharing the new project i have been working the last week. It is a microscope support conversion from a cheap universal drill press. The height of the microscope is adjusted with a threaded rod, driven by a stepper motor (Nema17). The stepper motor is controlled with an Arduino mini pro. There is a limit switch to detect the end of travel.

Electronic explannation with BoM will come soon.

BoM (not printed parts):

-2xM3x12 DIN912 fastener (stepper motor)
-2xM3x16 DIN912 fastener (stepper motor PCB Holder side)
-8xM4x20 DIN912 fastener (stepper motor holder, microscope holder and flange bearing)
-8xM4 DIN985 nut
-4xM8 DIN934 nut
-M8x30cm threaded rod

-1x D8mm flange bearing
-1x 8mm Nema17 coupling
-1x Nema17 Mottor
-1x Stepper motor driver
-1x Arduino mini pro

Apologies for not initially crediting m0214 for the design (now) linked to as a remix. I tried those stls but as the shape is open 180 degrees it didn't clip on for me and fell off, hence me recreating from scratch in OpenSCAD.

description.text:
This is a customizable inlay/drum for a rock tumbler.

I created this especially for a watertight container - the Leifheit 31202 (Link to german amazon-site)

I use the Leifheit-container a lot. Although it is 100% watertight I recommend sealing the lid of the Leifheit-container with some tape. The heavy pieces inside the container could press out the container-lid.
You should still put everything in a tub - just to be sure :)

The half-sphere you see on the lid is a grip to open the lid easier.
The hal-sphere at the bottom of the drum is because the Leifheit-Container has a "bump" at that spot.

ATTENTION: I do not update the files in thingiverse anymore. Download the latest version from my Google Drive: https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0BwsCFWbLCKZwSFFtbGFCeC1GSGs&usp=sharing#list After looking for a while for a 1.75mm, I decided to design my own.
First I tried some Direct Drive extruders available in the web..
The need for a motor fan for low Tg materials like PLA bored me.
The low resolution (low steps / mm) is not something pleasant to me..
And huge gap between the pinion and the filament output duct makes it difficult to push flexible filaments like Nylon..
So I came up with a geared 4:1 extruder, that has been working fine with many 1.75mm filaments, like ABS, PLA, Nylon and PET.
It is simple to assembly and low hardware parts count. Just download the correct extruder for your hotend, gears and Idler. Check Assembly Instructions for further information.
If you need the extruder for another hotend and/or hobbed bolt/pinion diameter, let me know on comments bellow.
Hotends provided:
  • Bowden
  • E3D V4/V5
  • Magma
  • JHead Generic
  • Sethi3D
  • 3DMachine
  • Movtech

ATTENTION: I do not update the files in thingiverse anymore. Download the latest version from my Google Drive: https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0BwsCFWbLCKZwVG5MSWQzQ1V6SWc&usp=sharing You will need four printed parts:
1) The right Extruder for your hotend;
The files are named as follow:
Alex-Extruder[Effective Hobbed Diameter][Hotend]
For example:
Alex-Extruder_8mm_E3D
is meant for E3D hotends and 8mm hobbed bolt (effective diameter of 7.6mm)
2) Idler
3) Hobbed Bolt Gear for your bolt
4) Motor gear;
All the files can be found in the ZIP package, just download the right one for your hobbed bolt/pulley.
The Washer.stl is optional and can be used tight the 8mm hobbed bolt with a nut.
For the extruder, you have some options. I have made, besides the generic JHead groove mount with 2 bolts, a "snap fit" mount for some specific hotends like E3D. You just need to insert the hotend in the right place and are ready to go.. no need for bolts, although I have provided a hole for a holding bolt if you fell more comfortable.
The same applies for the hobbed bolt. I have provided 2 versions, one for the regular 8mm hobbed bolt (with 7.6mm hobbed diameter) and other for MK8 pulley with M5 bolt.
If your hotend or hobbed bolt is not listed here (and probably will not), just ask me in the comments and I can provide you the right extruder... that's a way to make many versions available here.
To put the extruder together you will need:
Idler:
  • 1 625 bearing
  • 1 M5 x 25mm bolt to mount the bearing
  • 1 M3 x 25mm bolt to mount it in the Extruder
  • 1 M3 x 40mm bolt for spring
  • 1 clothspin spring (see pictures)
    Extruder:
  • Your favorite Hobbed Bolt or Pinion + Bolt;
  • 2 washer for your hobbed bolt.
  • 2x 688 bearings for 8mm Hobbed Bolt or 625 bearings for 5mm bolt;
  • 1 M3 nut for the spring bolt;
  • 3x M3 x 10mm bolts for mounting the step motor.
  • Optional washer and nut for the hobbed bolt. Since the gears are herringbone, they stay aligned...
  • Optional M3 x 16mm bolt for holding the snap fit hotend;
  • Optional 2x M3 x 25mm bolt for Generic JHead groove mount hotend.
    Pinion:
  • M3 nut;
  • M3 set screw
    Since the pinion is made for a flat shaft - it has a D hole - the above nut and set screw are optional but recommended for long term use.
    Then.... just put all together.. Recommendations:
  • Let the motor for the fina step.
  • Put the gears in contact and fix the bolts.. there is no need for pressing the gears... just touch them and fix the motor bolts.
  • Put 2 washers between the hobbed bolt gear and the extruder.
  • If you choose to use a nut in the hobbed bolt, DO NOT over tight it.. again, DO NOT over tight it.. just tight enough to TOUCH the washer in the bearing.. I mean, TOUCH, no pressure at all. A nyloc nut will avoid the nut from loosening.
  • If your "snap fitted" hotend is a little bit loose, use the M3x16mm to hold it in place. Again, DO NOT tight this bolt as well.. otherwise you will break the plastic piece.. just tight it to touch the hotend.
  • Do not over tight any bolt.. there is no need and you are dealing with plastic not metal.. just tight them to touch its counterpart.
    Printing recommendations:
  • Layer height = 0.2mm
  • 3 or 4 perimeters
  • 20% infill is enough
  • Use a layer width 0.4mm or less.
    For gears, I recommend printing external perimeter first.
    Your printer will need some bridging skills for printing the extruder, but it is not a big deal.

title: Customizable Bowden Extruder | Mount for ANET A8 & Others

description.text:
UPDATE March 28th: Added option for stronger V2 idler (with toggleable handle and additional fixation screw) in CUSTOMIZER

This is a remix of schlotzz's compact direct drive bowden extruder. All credit goes to schlotzz for the awesome bavarian engineering on this thing!

The design is highly customizable and works with MK7 or MK8 (and more) hobbed pulleys and features several mounting options! Some parametrization samples can be seen in picture 2.



This remix includes several improvements and adaptations:

  • CUSTOMIZER optimized (just open the customizer and generate a bowden extruder fitting your specific components!)
  • Different mount options available (Just a simple selection in the CUSTOMIZER toggles between no mount adapter, ANET A8 mount and parametrizable mounting bracket)
  • Option to add handle for manual tension release
  • Easily adjustable to any bowden pushfit ranging from M5 to M10



Please use the CUSTOMIZER to generate your suiting extruder! The files attached to this thing serve as examples only!



NOTE: If you switch your driving gear, you have to adapt your steps per mm of the extruder accordingly! Further informations and instructions regarding this topic can be found in the reprap wiki (click to jump to corresponding section).

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Supports highly recommended for ANET A8 mount option!
All other versions do not require supports.

Instructions
  • Use CUSTOMIZER to adapt mount to your specific hardware! Just go through all settings here...
  • Slice model and print base plate and idler separately (supports for version with ANET A8 mount required)
  • Use 2mm drill to clean filament path on base plate
  • Screw in your pushfit bowden connector
  • Attach 608zz bearing to idler and secure it with a M5 washer and a M5x10 screw
  • If using the ANET A8 mount: screw the mount to the top right of the printer frame (use stock screw and an additional M3x18 with suiting nut)
  • Attach NEMA17-Motor with three M3x8 (or M3x6) allen head screws (use countersunk holes)
  • Attach idler to base plate with a M3x16 screw (Avoid to much tension to allow idler moving freely)
  • Fasten hobbed pulley on NEMA17 stepper motor shaft. Align its position to the holes the filament is running trough
  • Insert M3 nut into base plate slot
  • Use M3 screw of suitable length with washers and a spring to apply pressure oan filament (For ANET A8 users: You can use the spring of the stock extruder! I added some M3 nuts in the core of the spring to keep it centered.)

title: Cigarette Case (Adapter for small BIC lighter)

description.text:
Hi, guys.

At first I printed this one thing made by 3DBrooklyn. Here it is: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:173316

But, in my country there's no such size of big BIC-lighter. After finishing printing I saw, that small BIC can't be installed on it's place.

Here's the adapter for small BIC Lighters (73-75 cm tall). The height of case is 95 cm. Print it on the original maker's page 3DBrooklyn: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:173316.

May be you'll required a bit sanding at the smallest partition (2.5mm) on the top side for better cigarette reject.

Print the model so as it in STL-file. No rotation required.
Good luck, and don't forget — smoking is killing you:)

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

title: Box for Almost Impossible Heart puzzle

description.text:
Created as a box for "Almost Impossible Heart". It's essentially an import of the heart shape, which is then slightly oversized and cut out of the top and bottom halves of a box. But it is parametric, and the OpenSCAD file can be used to import other STL files instead. Could be fun as a Play-Doh mold. Can adjust:
-height
-width
-depth
-size of bevel on top
-size of mating lip
-which .stl file is imported into the file
-amount to oversize the .stl cutout

To adjust it, edit the .scad file.  
The adjustable variables are listed at the top of the file.  
You can adjust "part_layout" to be either both pieces open for printing, closed, or spread apart slightly for general fit checks.  
Place whatever .stl you want to import in the same directory and replace "heart.stl" with the name of your part.  (also remove the "scale" directive above it--this was needed specifically for the Almost Impossible Heart Puzzle)  
Compile and Render with OpenSCAD, then Export as STL.

title: Tiny Whoop Type FPV Camera Mount and Cover

description.text:
Here’s an alternative camera mount and cover for Tiny Whoop type FPV quads. I bought a Makerfire version based on the Eachine E010 and decided to try moving the camera forward so the propellers wouldn’t be visible in the camera view. It doesn’t impact the balance of the quad and it flies fine with a much better view.

The Makerfire version has a connector for the camera. If your quad doesn't have a connector, make sure you put the camera into this mount prior to soldering the leads to the circuit board as the camera won't fit through the cover.

Also I haven't tried mounting this to other versions of the Tiny Whoop such as the Inductrix. If you print this and it doesn't fit other quads, let me know and I will add a warning that it only works for the Eachine E010.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I used Fusion 360 to design this part. The loft tool was essential to generating the swooping cover. And then I used Simplify 3D to slice it. Since this is a thin part, it was important to preview the printing see how each wall would be printed.

This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1043432 by Davideraffo.
Using a Raspbrry Pi 3 with the original case-design, swapping out the Micro-SD-Card was a pain. So i used Tinkercad customizing the case for the use with a Pi 3.

To mount the switch i used a M3x12 screw.

[quote]...
It is designed to encase a raspberry PI ... and a cooling fan 40x40x10 5V.
To complete the assembly I used:

N° 3 screws M4 x 20 with 3 M4 nuts (for the two cases)
N° 4 Screws M3 x 16 (that I cutted to 13) with 4 M3 Nuts (for the colling fan)
N° 4 Screws M2 x 12 (that I cutted to 8) with 4 M2 Nut (for the Raspberry board)
...[/quote]

You might need to use a ballpen or something other pointy to press the switch.

An animatronic tail controlled with gyro and joystick made with circuito.io: http://bit.ly/circuitoio-tail-components

The full tutorial is on hackster.io: http://bit.ly/circuitoio-tail-on-hackster

Spinous process - The processes sit at the base of every part of every vertebra and is connected to the spinal cord in the middle of the tail. There are 11 processes in the tail model.

Pulley - Use a fishing line to connect between the pulley and the servo motor to make the tail move from side to side. You will need to print 3 pullies - one for each side and one for the top servo.

Bar Mount - The Bar mount is connected to the main plate of the tail, and through it runs the spinal cord.

Servo Mount right - need to print this part 3 times. The mount holds the servo motor from its right side.

Servo Mount left - need to print this part 3 times. The mount holds the servo motor from its left side.

Tail tip - The part at the end of the tail. Needs to be printed once

Laser cut - this file contains the parts that need to be laser-cut. There are 11 vertebrae and one main plate.

Spinal cord:
For the spinal cord we used a flexible round Okolon bar.
Dimensions: 1x 0.6cm diameter x100cm length

Screws:
22x M3 screws 10mm length with bullets

Fishing line:
3.5 meters fishing string made of spectra fiber 0.23mm 15kg (powerpro.com)

title: Mushroom slug trap / Piège à  limaces Champignon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of the slug trap from AlexEnglish (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23467)

Improvements: new mushroom-shaped design and 3 eyelets in order to anchor the trap on the ground in case of strong wind.

This is a slug trap for killing slugs in the garden. Print (body in white beige and hat in red for example). Take a beer. You can drink it a little before :-) and fill about 2/3 the way full. Put the hat on, and place in the garden.

Slugs will be out more when it's raining or has recently rained; the hat helps the water run off so the rain won't dilute the beer and make the trap ineffective.

C'est un remix du piège à limace de AlexEnglish (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23467)

Améliorations : nouveau design en forme de champignon et 3 œilletons pour pouvoir ancrer le piège au sol en cas de vent fort.

Ce piège à limace est un piège pour tuer par noyade les limaces dans le jardin. Imprimez (le corps en blanc beige et le chapeau en rouge par exemple). Prenez une bière. Vous pouvez en boire un petit peu avant :-) et remplissez le récipient au 2/3. Mettez le couvercle (chapeau du champignon),et placez le piège dans le jardin.

Les limaces sortent quand il pleut ou quand il a plu récemment ; le chapeau (couvercle) protège la bière de la pluie et évite la dilution qui rendrait le piège inefficace.

Print, fill with beer, put the lid on, and place in the garden. You'll want to place the trap near plants that slugs have been attacking, or near a place where you know the slugs are coming from. Likely hotspots include the edges of raised beds, any boards, logs, bricks, or rocks nearby, and dense undisturbed foliage like unmowed grass and weed patches.

Imprimez et remplissez avec de la bière. Mettez le couvercle (chapeau) et placez dans le jardin.Vous placerez le piège près des plantes attaquées par les limaces ou près des endroits d'ou elles peuvent provenir (bordures, planches, bûches, briques ou pierres, roches, feuillages denses, hautes herbes, mauvaises herbes, etc...).

title: Hangable, removable, exchangeable, storage mini cube box.

description.text: I designed this box to be able to store tools and parts I use often in my workshop. I also wanted to be able to more efficiently use the space under my shelves, so I made brackets you can screw under the shelves (or anywhere) and hang the cube box from them. There are two types of brackets, a single sided one that only holds one side of the cube, or a double one that can be used between two cubes.
